author: Contributed Report
title: 'Telling Amy's Story'
text: Comment By Contributed Report Posted Oct. 25, 2015 @ 2:01 am HOPEWELL — The Tri-Cities Regional Domestic Violence Taskforce, in partnership with James House, is hosting a screening of “Telling Amy’s Story,” the powerful story of a mother killed by her abusive husband and the steps that could have been taken to alter the outcome. The screening will be held Monday at Destination Theater, 5246 Oaklawn Boulevard from 7 to 8:30 p.m. Doors will open at 6:30 p.m. and refreshments will be available for purchase. This event is free, however, registration is requested. To register, contact KeKe Cody at 458-2704 ext. 223; leave your full name, phone number and number of people in your party. The Tri-Cities Regional Domestic Violence Taskforce. with Honorary Chairperson Senator Rosalyn R. Dance, D-16th, is a multi-jurisdictional collaboration that seeks to end domestic violence through coordinated prevention, intervention, community education, and advocacy efforts. James House provides support, advocacy and education for people affected by sexual violence, domestic violence and stalking, to empower them to become healthy, safe, and self-sufficient. The only nonprofit agency in the Tri-Cities area accredited by the Virginia Sexual and Domestic Violence Action Alliance, all James House services are cost-free and confidential. For more information, call 458-2704, visit www.thejameshouse.org; or email helpline@thejameshouse.org.
